item.title: Nomads thrived in Greece after the collapse of the Roman Empire
item.dc:creator: admins
item.description:

The post Nomads thrived in Greece after the collapse of the Roman Empire appeared first on PRN Arizona State University.
item.content:encoded:
An analysis of pollen from Lake Volvi in Greece has unexpectedly revealed that nomads thrived in this region for centuries after the chaos unleashed by the collapse of the Roman Empire.

Adam Izdebski at the Max Planck Institute of Geoanthropology in Germany and his colleagues were studying sediment cores from the lake as part of a larger study. As lake sediments build up, changes in the abundance of various kinds of pollen in the sediment layers can record how nearby vegetation changed over time.

In some other places around the Mediterranean, the team has found signs of reforestation after the collapse of the Western Roman Empire around AD 476. But at Lake Volvi, from around AD 540, the team found less tree pollen but more pollen from plants associated with nomadic livestock herders. These nomads were returning to the same areas seasonally, so planted some crops, such as barley.

“We have this moment when the Roman agriculture disappears almost completely due to plague, climate change and warfare, but you don’t get reforestation – you actually get less forest very quickly,” says Izdebski.

“The landscape was dominated by pasture animals even in the high mountain areas. This was a complete shift from how the Romans farmed the lowlands for several hundred years.”

This means those earlier farmers moved away, died or adopted a nomadic lifestyle, he says.

Greece was nominally under the control of the Eastern Roman, or Byzantine, Empire around at the time of this shift. It is known that the region was raided by Bulgar nomads around AD 540, but it wasn’t known that nomads lived in this region for several centuries.

The only historical information that correlates with the team’s findings is an account of a Byzantine emperor being ambushed by Bulgar nomads around AD 700.

“It seems that there was a local society that didn’t want any emperor to be around,” says Izdebski, who presented the findings at the meeting of the European Geosciences Union in Vienna, Austria, last month.

Around AD 850, the Byzantine Empire reasserted control and the signs of nomads disappear. Instead, there was reforestation.

The findings provide rare evidence of the presence of nomadic peoples at a particular place and time, says Izdebski. “We know very little about their history because the states were not interested in recording them.”

Historians didn’t write about nomadic peoples as they weren’t part of the elites, he says. And because nomads were difficult to tax, there are no tax records either – tax records can be a rich source of information about past populations.

item.title: Keto diet may accelerate organ ageing
item.dc:creator: admins
item.description:

Their build-up suggests the keto diet may accelerate organ ageing, raising the risk of conditions like heart disease and cancer. Although many people have adopted low-carbohydrate diets […]

The post Keto diet may accelerate organ ageing appeared first on PRN Arizona State University.
item.content:encoded:
A ketogenic diet causes damaged cells to accumulate in the organs of mice. Their build-up suggests the keto diet may accelerate organ ageing, raising the risk of conditions like heart disease and cancer.

Although many people have adopted low-carbohydrate diets like keto for weight loss and controlling blood sugar, research on their health effects is mixed, with some studies finding they increase the risk of heart attacks.

To learn more, David Gius at the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio and his colleagues fed six mice a ketogenic diet for three weeks. More than 90 per cent of their calories came from fat and less than 1 per cent from carbohydrates. A control group ate a standard diet where 17 per cent of calories came from fat and 58 per cent came from carbohydrates.

The researchers then analysed heart, kidney, liver and brain tissue samples from the mice, looking for senescent cells. Senescence occurs when cells become too damaged to function, but instead of dying, they enter a zombie-like state. These cells linger in tissues, spewing toxins that stoke inflammation.

Animals on the ketogenic diet had significantly more senescent cells in their organs compared with those on a standard diet. For instance, their kidneys contained, on average, four times the amount of a marker of cellular senescence as those from animals fed a regular diet.

Senescent cells increase with age. So, these findings suggest the keto diet might accelerate organ ageing, which would raise the risk of conditions like heart disease, cancer and type 2 diabetes. However, switching mice back to a standard diet decreased senescent cells.

“While the ketogenic diet is probably a good thing, [it is not for] everyone. And importantly, you need to take a break,” says Gius. “I think our paper really says we need to study this more rigorously.”

It isn’t clear how these experimental findings may translate to people, says Russell Jones at the Van Andel Institute in Michigan. “They’re running a 90 per cent fat diet, and that would be virtually impossible to adhere to as a human,” he says.

Physics is in a crisis. Over the past year, a series of research papers claimed to find evidence for high-temperature superconductors – materials that conduct electricity without losses, which could revolutionise global energy use. These were retracted after all efforts to reproduce them failed, and in some cases original data was shown to have been falsified. item.content:encoded:
Hold onto your spacesuits! Astronomers have unveiled the discovery of a rocky planet eerily similar to Earth, reigniting our quest for extraterrestrial life. Located a mere 55 light-years away – a cosmic hop in astronomical terms – this newfound world has sparked excitement amongst scientists, offering a tantalizing glimpse into a potential abode for life beyond our solar system.

A Rocky Replica: Unveiling SPECULOOS-3 b

The newfound planet, aptly named SPECULOOS-3 b, orbits a cool red dwarf star within the constellation Sextans. Classified as an “exoplanet,” meaning it resides outside our solar system, SPECULOOS-3 b is roughly the size of Earth. This similarity in size alone has astronomers buzzing, as it places SPECULOOS-3 b within the range of potentially harboring conditions suitable for life as we know it.

While Earth is bathed in the warm glow of our Sun, SPECULOOS-3 b orbits a much cooler and fainter red dwarf star. This raises questions about the planet’s potential habitability. Here’s a breakdown of what we know so far:

  • The Goldilocks Zone: Maybe Not Quite Right – Our Sun emits a range of radiation, and planets within a specific zone around it receive the right amount of heat to allow liquid water to exist on their surfaces – a key ingredient for life. Unfortunately, SPECULOOS-3 b orbits its star much closer than Earth orbits the Sun. This close proximity might subject the planet to scorching temperatures, potentially rendering its surface unsuitable for life.

  • Tidally Locked Dance: Another intriguing aspect of SPECULOOS-3 b is the possibility that it’s tidally locked with its star. This means one side of the planet perpetually faces the star, basking in its constant light, while the other side remains in perpetual darkness. Such extremes in temperature could potentially create a thin atmosphere on the dayside, while the nightside remains frigid.

Beyond Habitability: A New Frontier for Planetary Science

While the jury’s still out on whether SPECULOOS-3 b could support life, its discovery holds immense significance for our understanding of planetary formation. Here’s why:

  • Rocky Companions for Cool Stars: Red dwarf stars are the most common type of star in our galaxy. Prior to SPECULOOS-3 b, very few rocky planets had been found orbiting these cooler stars. This discovery suggests that rocky planets may be more prevalent around red dwarfs than previously thought.

  • A Laboratory for Studying Alien Geology: SPECULOOS-3 b’s proximity to Earth makes it a prime candidate for further study. Powerful telescopes like the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) could potentially analyze the planet’s atmosphere, if it has one, revealing its composition and searching for biosignatures – potential signs of life. Additionally, studying the geology of SPECULOOS-3 b could shed light on how planets form around different types of stars.

The Search Continues: A Universe Teeming with Possibilities

The discovery of SPECULOOS-3 b adds another exciting chapter to humanity’s ongoing quest to find life beyond Earth. While this particular planet might not be our cosmic twin, it serves as a powerful reminder that our solar system is just one tiny speck in a vast and potentially teeming universe.

Astronomers are constantly scanning the skies for new exoplanets, and with each discovery, we get closer to finding a world that could truly be called Earth’s “twin.” The hunt for extraterrestrial life is no longer science fiction; it’s a scientific endeavor filled with promise, and discoveries like SPECULOOS-3 b fuel our collective imagination and inspire us to reach for the stars.

item.content:encoded:
Microsoft’s annual Build conference, held earlier this week, is a developer-focused event that serves as a window into the company’s vision for the future. This year’s conference was no different, brimming with exciting announcements that showcased Microsoft’s continued push towards artificial intelligence (AI) integration across its products and services.

While developers received a deep dive into the technical aspects of these advancements, here’s a breakdown of the key announcements for everyone to get excited about:

1. Copilot Everywhere: Your AI Companion Takes Flight

Remember Copilot, the AI-powered coding assistant that took the developer world by storm? Well, get ready to see it woven into the fabric of your entire Microsoft experience. The star of the show, Copilot, is expanding its reach beyond Visual Studio Code.

  • Windows 11 Gets a Brainy Boost: Imagine a helpful AI sidekick right on your taskbar. Build announced Copilot integration directly into Windows 11. This translates to a sidebar chatbot accessible with a single click. Leveraging ChatGPT technology, it provides context-aware assistance, drawing from your emails, calendar, and documents stored on OneDrive and SharePoint.

  • Supercharge Your Workflow Across Apps: Copilot won’t be confined to Windows. Microsoft is integrating it into various applications like Microsoft 365, offering real-time grammar suggestions, data analysis help within Excel, and even intelligent slide creation in PowerPoint.

2. The Rise of the AI-Powered Bing:

Microsoft’s search engine, Bing, is no stranger to innovation. This year’s Build confirmed its continued focus on AI integration. The biggest news? Bing now supports ChatGPT as its default search experience.

This integration unlocks a new level of search capabilities:

  • Unleashing the Power of ChatGPT: No longer limited to pre-2021 information, ChatGPT can now access and process real-time web data through Bing’s powerful search engine. This means you’ll get more comprehensive and up-to-date results to your queries.

  • Citations for Credibility: A major drawback of large language models has been the lack of source attribution. Bing Chat now addresses this by including citations within its responses, allowing you to explore the sources behind the information and validate its accuracy.

3. A New Era for Developers: Azure Embraces AI

Developers are the backbone of technological progress, and Microsoft isn’t leaving them behind in the AI revolution. Build 2024 saw a significant focus on Azure, Microsoft’s cloud computing platform, with several AI-powered tools designed to empower developers:

  • Low-Code Development Gets Smarter: Citizen developers, those without extensive coding experience, can now leverage AI-powered tools within Azure to build applications. This removes technical barriers and allows more people to contribute to the development process.

  • The Democratization of Machine Learning: Building complex machine learning models has traditionally required specialized expertise. Azure is introducing user-friendly AI tools that streamline the process, making machine learning more accessible to a wider range of developers.

4. The Future of Communication: Microsoft Teams Gets a Makeover

Microsoft Teams, the ubiquitous collaboration platform, is receiving an AI upgrade to enhance communication and productivity:

  • Real-Time Language Translation: Imagine a world where language barriers cease to exist in your team meetings. Build announced real-time translation capabilities within Teams, allowing seamless communication between participants speaking different languages.

  • Smarter Meetings with AI Assistants: Microsoft is developing AI assistants for Teams that can take notes, summarize discussions, and even identify action items during meetings. This frees up participants to focus on the conversation and streamlines post-meeting tasks.

5. The Internet of Things Gets a Security Boost

The Internet of Things (IoT) is rapidly expanding, but security concerns remain a major hurdle. Build addressed this with the announcement of Azure Sphere, a new security framework specifically designed for IoT devices.

Azure Sphere integrates AI to proactively identify and mitigate security threats, ensuring the safety and integrity of your connected devices.

Beyond the Headlines: A Look Ahead

The announcements at Build 2024 paint a clear picture of Microsoft’s vision for the future: a world powered by AI. From intelligent assistants to enhanced communication tools and even an AI-driven search engine, Microsoft is placing its bets on AI to revolutionize the way we work, learn, and interact with technology.

While some may be apprehensive about the growing influence of AI, there’s no denying its potential to improve our lives. Build 2024 showcased Microsoft’s commitment to developing responsible AI that empowers users and fosters a more productive and collaborative future.
